Award.AwardTitle: Vertical Integration of Raman Spectroscopy into the Chemistry Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The faculty in the Chemistry and Biochemistry Department at Florida Atlantic University are vertically integrating Raman spectroscopy experiments and experiences into the undergraduate chemistry curriculum. The project is addressing key, course-specific, student learning outcomes as well as fundamental, anchoring concepts ('big ideas'). The project is accomplishing this by acquiring a sophisticated Raman spectrometer and is using this instrument to introduce and reinforce increasingly more complex chemistry concepts as a student progresses through the course sequence. This project is part of a restructured chemistry curriculum that includes a 'spectroscopy-to-learn' approach. Raman spectroscopy is aiding students' deep learning of molecular structure, quantitative analysis, the elucidation of reaction mechanisms, and how spectroscopy aids research.

The project is demonstrating and establishing the methods by which a sophisticated spectroscopic instrument can be utilized throughout the entire chemistry curriculum to promote understanding of anchoring concepts at all levels. Students are engaging with increasingly more advanced Raman instrument-based experiments as they progress through the chemistry curriculum enabling them to: (1) connect the theory taught in lectures with authentic research and industry practice; (2) become more active and responsible participants in their own learning; and (3) reinforce and extend their understanding of concepts previously learned. Independent consultants are guiding the evaluation of the effectiveness of this effort aimed at the over-arching ideas of improving student understanding of chemical principles and their attitudes towards learning.

The student body of the FAU campus ensures a diverse population is experiencing a hands-on encounter with state-of-the-art instrumentation. The investigators are disseminating their work through presentations and a dedicated web site. In addition, an illustrated handbook featuring the novel undergraduate Raman experiences and experiments is being prepared for publication. An instructor's manual that contains both pre- and post-measures of learning outcomes is also being developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project is unique in that we have implemented Raman spectroscopy experiments and experiences into the entire undergraduate chemistry curriculum at Florida Atlantic University to enhance: (1) student learning, (2) critical thinking skills and (3) preparedness of our students for future success in the workforce, both in academia and industry. These activities range from simple demonstrations of molecular vibrations utilizing spring loaded devices in introductory chemistry, to elucidation of chemical structures using Raman spectroscopy in organic chemistry, to advanced experiments involving analysis of pharmaceutical formulations, plastic polymers, and reaction kinetics using Raman microscopy in analytical and physical chemistry. 

We are using a single cutting-edge research instrument, the Raman microscope/spectrometer, as a teaching tool throughout the entire undergraduate chemistry curriculum. In this model, as students progress through the curriculum, they benefit from repeated exposure to a high-end Raman microscope and use this instrument to investigate and understand many chemical principles of increasing complexity. This model employs active and tactile learning with increased complexity at each consecutive exposure to Raman. Thus, we are methodically building our students’ interest and learning of chemical concepts as well as their comfort and skill in operating high-end instrumentation, and their ability to apply Raman spectroscopy to study and solve problems. Our students are this nation’s future workforce destined for industry and academia. Their ability to quickly solve scientific problems and use complex instrumentation is key to this nation’s long-term success and prosperity.

We developed and will publish eight novel Raman-based activities for teaching key concepts in freshman, sophomore, junior and senior lab courses in the chemistry curriculum. We are evaluating changes in student learning, critical thinking skills, and attitudes toward learning as a result of their experiences in our enriched curriculum, especially in the General Chemistry 2 Lab course. We have found that many of the General Chemistry 2 Lab students who experienced the Raman-enriched curriculum have made gains in their critical thinking skills, such as evaluation, induction, and deduction abilities, as well as having significantly enhanced their performance in general chemistry tests (by ~ 13%).

We are disseminating at annual American Chemical Society national meetings and a dedicated web site (http://www.science.fau.edu/chemistry/Raman@FAU/index.html). We will publish developed activities and results in the Journal of Chemical Education. An instructor's manual and illustrated handbook will be published. This will facilitate the adoption of this approach by other higher education institutions in the US. All freshman science majors (~1000/semester) at FAU are impacted by this project through a hands-on activity about molecular vibrations, intended to teach and excite students about chemistry and molecular spectroscopy. All chemistry majors at FAU are impacted by this project (~ 200/year). Our students and their TAs are becoming highly skilled in using and applying Raman spectroscopy to study and solve chemical problems.
